4.80.text:
>> Jamie Bonini: So, first of all, as Hollie
mentioned, I come from a group at Toyota that

11.41.text:
since the early ’90s we have been helping
organizations outside Toyota learn and implement

20.26.text: And we’ve done that in two settings.

22.24.text:
One is with small to midsize manufacturing
companies to strength manufacturing in North

27.02.text:
America with the goal of more jobs, better
jobs.

31.81.text:
The second half of what we do is we work with
nonprofit organizations. This would be healthcare,

38.04.text:
food banks, as Hollie mentioned, disaster
recovery, American Red Cross, and governments.

43.92.text:
And in the governments, we’ve worked at
the municipality level, we’ve worked at

48.24.text:
the state level, and we’ve worked in Washington,
D.C.

52.89.text: We find those projects really very interesting.

55.23.text:
And I really enjoyed what I heard yesterday,
and I had a chance to visit some of your agencies

63.17.text:
So, my perspective that I have to share with
you today is what have we learned about helping

67.75.text:
organizations outside Toyota that are in the
beginning and middle phases of their journey.

75.60.text:
With that in mind, I have three points that
I want to share with you.

80.13.text:
First, I want to summarize what is the Toyota
Production System?

86.44.text:
As we describe TPS outside Toyota, the Toyota
Production System is an organizational culture

95.32.text:
that is an integrated system of three key
elements.

98.75.text:
It starts off with a basic philosophy about
how you’re going to run the operation.

103.52.text:
That philosophy underlies a host of technical
tools under that auspices of Just-in-Time

111.21.text:
And the third piece of this integrated system
is a managerial role to develop people to

119.12.text:
So, for us, that’s TPS: an organizational
culture with a philosophy, technical tools,

124.43.text:
and managerial role all working together as
a system.

128.67.text:
Second thing I want to share with you is how
we have found effective to help organizations

135.84.text:
And that approach we call the Model Line Approach.
And Jim talked about that yesterday.

142.22.text:
And that approach basically says take a narrow
slice of the organization, and implement TPS

147.89.text:
in that narrow slice, in your case, maybe
a process within an organization, and implement

157.06.text:
And what that means is in that narrow area,
the philosophy is at play, the right technical

161.77.text:
tools are at play for that process, and the
managerial role is working at a very high

166.32.text:
level to develop people to surface problems
and solve problems to create a -- a high powered

175.91.text:
And then what we do is once we have a very
good working model area, we learn how it applies

181.05.text:
to that operation, which is not Toyota, and
then we have people that can spread it to

186.01.text:
the next model line to the next model line
model line to the next model line to the next

191.79.text:
And I’m going to illustrate that approach
with four examples.

195.86.text:
First is a manufacturing example from a Herman
Miller company in Western Michigan.

200.75.text: Second is from the City of Louisville, Kentucky.

203.11.text:
Third will be a medical example from a hospital
in Los Angeles.

207.12.text:
And lastly, I’ll share what we have been
doing with the State of New York that benchmarked

212.93.text:
They’re much earlier in their journey than
you, but I can share with you what we’ve

215.88.text:
been doing with them for the last two years
in New York.

220.12.text:
That’s the second piece of my talk, is about
the model line.

223.59.text:
And then finally, I want to share with you
some perspectives on what we have learned

231.60.text:
And I will share five points at the end that’s
sort of a broad view about what we see as

236.02.text:
general themes that I think will build up
on very well what we heard yesterday.

240.23.text: So, that’s what I have for you.

244.01.text:
A little background about Toyota first.
You’ll probably be familiar with us.

248.28.text:
We build about 2 million vehicles a year here

253.99.text: You see some of the statistics there.

And we do have a component plant up here in

275.07.text:
And just a little bit about -- more about

282.68.text: all over -- all over the country.

And a little bit of work up here in this Pacific

I wanted to share with you some statics since

There are 30 dealers that employ almost 3,000
people.

And they do make investments in expanding

309.28.text: Okay. That’s the big picture about Toyota.

312.87.text:
Let me tell you about the group that I come

315.91.text:
The group is called TSSC. Our mission is contribute
to society by sharing the Toyota Production

322.88.text:
System knowledge with public institutions
and help strengthen manufacturing in North

328.33.text:
And this has been our mission for over 20
years.

332.27.text:
A little bit about our history.
We heard some of this yesterday.

335.28.text:
In 1987, we opened a large factory near Lexington,
Kentucky. There’s a photograph of it there.

341.47.text:
And some of the books that were written at
that time talked a little bit about TPS.

345.48.text:
So, we got some visitors that wanted to come
visit our factory.

349.70.text:
In 1990, Jim Womack published the book that
he talked about yesterday, “The Machine

353.51.text:
that Changed the World,” that coined the
term “Lean Production.”

357.13.text:
And when that happened, we were swamped with
visitors.

361.61.text:
Completely overwhelmed with people wanting
to come in on tours and wanted to learn about

366.09.text:
So, in 1992, we opened up TSSC, the group
that I come from, and we have been working

375.60.text: And then in 2011, we became a nonprofit subsidiary.

378.06.text: So, that’s a little bit of history.

380.90.text:
Over that time, we have completed, shown here,
about 270 projects. These are three months

389.49.text:
These are projects to implement TPS in a whole
variety of settings, as shown there on the

395.87.text:
Some automotive suppliers, but education,
food, furniture, healthcare, nonprofits, all

403.04.text: This year, we will support 50 organizations.

Forty percent of those will be showing on
the left, will be businesses that are small

409.94.text:
to midsize organizations doing manufacturing
of various sorts or other sort of industrial

417.80.text:
And 60% will be what we call social contribution
or nonprofits: healthcare, hunger relief,

423.76.text:
like the food banks, disaster recovery, social
services, and government.

431.21.text:
When we work with organizations, we work very
closely on the shop floor to establish a model

437.58.text:
We develop people through the model line who
can then spread the TPS from the model line

442.84.text:
And the vast majority of this is hands-on,
learn-by-doing. We heard a lot about that

448.56.text:
We do supplement this with some training in
one- to two-day formats of the type of workshops

455.23.text: that I have listed over there.

456.90.text: We heard a lot about this content yesterday.

458.76.text:
My point that I want to emphasize is our approach
to this is most of this is on the shop floor,

464.31.text:
making improvements with training introduced
just-in-time as needed to get the right concepts

468.67.text: at the right time to do the implementation.

473.31.text:
Now, I will describe what is TPS. This is
TPS as we describe it on one slide.

478.18.text:
It is an organizational culture that is an
integrated system.

481.84.text: It starts off with a philosophy.

483.76.text: The philosophy has four key points.

488.13.text: Second is people are the most valuable resource.

492.26.text: And four is shop floor focused.

494.86.text:
That philosophy underlies the technical tools
that I will elaborate on in a moment.

500.28.text:
But the key point about the tools is: use
the right tools correctly for the process

503.80.text: at hand from a systems viewpoint.

506.62.text:
And those technical tools require the philosophy
to work appropriately.

510.43.text:
And then, finally, most critically, I think,
is the managerial or leadership role, which

514.54.text:
is to motivate and develop people to surface
and solve problems, and build this high engagement

521.72.text:
And that’s why we have people development
in the center.

524.40.text:
We heard a lot of that yesterday by all sorts
of people, which I thought was just terrific.

529.13.text: Here is the technical piece of the system.

532.74.text:
In the roof of this TPS house are the results
that we’re after.

536.27.text:
The results are safety first, above all.
Then we want very high quality.

541.68.text:
Very low cost.
And very short lead-time.

544.02.text:
Lead time is the time between when a customer
makes an order and when a product or service

549.28.text:
To get that, those results, there are two
main pillars of the Toyota Production System.

554.44.text:
Just-in-time shown on the left, which is about
establishing flow.

557.15.text:
And when you have a high level of flow, when
the flow is disrupted, you can see problems.

561.61.text:
You can see the flow disruption.
That’s intentional.

564.88.text: See the problems that block the flow.

566.80.text:
And then secondly is built-in quality or Judoka,
and that basically says that every step of

572.17.text: the process we want to have be self-diagnosing.

574.71.text:
Meaning if it isn’t done properly or there’s
an error, a signal arises.

580.59.text:
An everyday example of Judoka would be in
your vehicle.

584.05.text:
If you get in your vehicle, your passenger
does not fasten their seatbelt properly and

590.98.text:
Bing, bing, bing, bing, bing, bing.
That’s Judoka.

595.54.text:
A step was not completed and there’s an
immediate signal.

599.43.text:
Okay? So the idea behind TPS is have a high
amount of flow, have a high amount of Judoka,

605.84.text:
with the flow in Judoka lots of problems are
going to come to the surface, and we’re

609.46.text:
going to couple that with an organization
of legions of problem-solvers that can solve

614.03.text:
those problems, contain them, and most importantly,
prevent them from happening again.

618.37.text:
So, it is fundamentally a problem-solving
system.

622.22.text:
So, with that in mind, how have we found effective
to help organizations implement TPS?

628.91.text: And Jim talked about this yesterday.

630.69.text:
Basically, we use this model line approach
that says we take a narrow slice of the organization

635.37.text:
-- in a manufacturing setting it would be
from shipping to receiving -- in the government

639.27.text:
setting, we have used a process within an
agency and I’ll give you an example in a

643.04.text:
moment, and we try to implement TPS in great
depth in that narrow area.

647.29.text:
So, if we see the model line there on the
right in yellow, what I want to emphasize

651.85.text:
is in that narrow process, and in the government
setting there might be 15 to 20 people involved

657.25.text:
in that, we want to implement TPS in great
depth in that narrow area.

663.40.text:
That means we have to have that whole triangle
working, the philosophy at play, the right

667.55.text:
technical tools shown at the house on the
right, and the managerial role.

672.41.text:
One key point about the managerial role is
for the leadership, and we heard a lot about

676.28.text:
leadership yesterday and there was a lot of
questions about leadership.

679.83.text:
From our perspective, there are four key roles
we want the leaders to demonstrate on this

685.09.text:
Those are, one, very strong visible commitment.
I think you have that here, for sure.

689.79.text:
Two, understanding TPS correctly.
That means learn the principles and the details.

694.89.text:
Three, make problems visible.
Build a culture to expose problems.

699.32.text:
And lastly, be very active on the Gemba or
a Genchi Genbutsu, meaning that the leaders

704.55.text:
need to be very active in the process to understand
the inner workings of the process by seeing

710.28.text:
So, on this slide is what we’re trying to
create with these model lines.

Okay, now I’m going to illustrate this with

720.62.text:
then I’ve got several other examples to

730.00.text:
So, Herman Miller is a furniture maker in

Their headquarters is in western Michigan

772.94.text:
Now, this was a time when a lot of furniture

786.14.text:
And they reached out to us to say, “Can

1005.54.text:

1010.82.text:
So, when we pick a model line, we’re looking

1014.30.text:
for improvement in either safety first, quality,
lead time, or productivity.

1019.35.text:
Two, it’s feasible to make major improvements

1024.35.text:

lines done in three months.

1029.70.text:
Maybe six in some areas. But that’s -- that
to me is what we work towards.

1034.76.text:
Thirdly, we need strong operational leaders,
and we heard a lot about this yesterday, that

1038.80.text:
are humble, eager, and will learn TPS by doing
it.

1043.12.text:
These includes the executives, and the supervisors,
and the line management.

1046.90.text:

1053.10.text:

1057.19.text:
it’s a logical place that we can then go

1061.21.text:

So, we start with one model line and then

and spread it, model line and spread it, model

This is so you can grow this culture by doing

1105.09.text:
because the different agencies or group will

1506.67.text:
This is a hospital called Harbor UCLA in Los

1509.52.text:
It’s a medical teaching hospital affiliated
with UCLA.

1516.49.text:
They mostly serve under-served patients. Medicare,
Medicaid, and many are uninsured.

1520.77.text:

headquarters there.

1524.79.text:
When they came and approached us two years
ago, the CEO had started a Lean strategy because

1529.98.text: he needed to do more with less.

1531.47.text:

and other places, heard about Lean.

1536.33.text:
We visited. We scoped out three options for
an initial model area. And we choose an eye

1541.36.text: clinic. This is an ophthalmology clinic.

in the video.

1546.70.text:

meeting and we were talking about what area.

1550.65.text:

1562.64.text:

1571.67.text:

1577.42.text:

1582.39.text: clinic and it’s been an unsolvable problem.”

1995.16.text:

Okay. The last thing I want to share, and

2022.94.text:

2026.67.text:
So, as I mentioned, New York State came out

2035.28.text:

2042.63.text:
Choi, presented early in September at a national

2047.01.text:
I’m not going to go through all the points,
but I’m just going to give you a few things

2050.34.text:
to give you a feel the impact you’re having
on other states, and make a few comments about

2055.22.text:
some of the approaches they’re using that
have found effective that may be of value

2060.66.text:
So, how did Lean get started in New York State
government?

2064.38.text:
There was a recommendation from a special
commission called “Spending and Government

2068.61.text:
Efficiency” as a method to improve efficiency
and effectiveness in delivering services that

2073.62.text: they felt they had to do to operational improvement.

2075.73.text:
They started their planning in 2013 and they
kicked off in July.

2080.50.text:
It was modeled after Washington State, and
using pro bono private sector partners.

2094.87.text:
What they wanted to do was not just process
transformation, but build a cultural transformation

2101.27.text:
Their first department that they -- we were
one of the corporate partners. They have several

2106.56.text:
They asked us to work with the Department
of Health, and we created an initial model

2111.12.text:
line there and we’ve worked on 16 other
projects. We have another six on the way.

2117.82.text:
An “empire belt” is their term for a TPS
leader of some form that works on TPS full

2128.21.text:
What they wanted to try to do overall is change
the culture in their agency by engaging employees,

2132.89.text:
especially on the front line, implementing
consistent, repeatable, and transformable

2139.33.text:
So, they’re trying to figure out what’s
going to be their common approach for implementing

2143.01.text:
Lean, get some good prototypes for that, and
then share that with the different agencies

2147.44.text:
so they don’t have a lot of different approaches
going on in different agencies.

2150.45.text: They want to experiment to get to a good method.

2153.22.text:
And then ultimately, have this self-sustaining
at all the agencies.

2156.84.text:
This is the approach that we have used working
with them.

2159.85.text:
So, on the bottom there, in the circles there,
these are Kaizen teams that would work on

2165.23.text:
a model line project over about a three-month
period.

2168.96.text:
On that project team would be led by an empire
belt, shown by EB in the middle.

2173.83.text:
Those empire belts or their TPS leaders are
coached by a master or a lead empire belt.

2181.30.text:
So, they have a coach coaching the coaches,
and our role is to coach the coach of the

2186.15.text: So, that sounds kind of a little bit intricate.

2190.09.text:
But the point is, we’re coaching them to
coach their people to build their TPS capability

2196.13.text:
is the role that we’ve taken with them and
found is pretty efficient for everyone.

2200.30.text: It seems to be working pretty well.

2202.41.text:
So far, they’re working with 38 agencies.
They have 305 projects at different form completed.

2209.54.text:
They’ve trained over 400 of these empire
belts.

2211.82.text: They’ve got close to 6,000 workers engaged.

2214.49.text:
And they worked on processes pretty similar
to what I heard here today and -- well, not

2218.51.text:
today, but yesterday and the day before, licensing,
enforcement, contracting, and overall responsiveness

2223.42.text:
or lead time, which we’ve heard the last
two days.

2227.93.text:
This is the original model line project that
we did with the Department of Health.

2232.01.text:
They have a certificate of need process. I’m
sure you have something like that here.

2235.92.text:
They were getting complaints from the healthcare
providers and healthcare associations that

2240.12.text: the permitting process took too long.

2242.92.text:
It was taking 137 days, which is a major complaint
by the hospitals.

2247.58.text:
So, we worked and analyzed that and over a
three-month period created a starting point

2252.46.text:
for a model line, targeted to get it to 32
days.

2256.05.text:
Now, we have it down to a little less than
47, and we got that done in a couple months.

2263.06.text:
They were very, very pleased when some of
the senior people from the healthcare agencies

2267.80.text:
that had been complaining at a very high level
in the government called up and said, “We

2273.40.text:
can’t believe what you’ve done. You’ve
done a complete 180. We’re really amazed

2277.67.text:
at the improvement you’ve done in a short
period of time.”

2279.92.text:
So, they were very pleased with those results
in a couple-month period.

2283.24.text:
Here’s some of the example of the process

2288.14.text:
Here are some of the broader benefits throughout
what they’re seeing in their two years.

2292.97.text:
The workforce sees benefits of developing
leaders for the future. People see these as

2296.98.text:
portable skills to go to different agencies,
and a lot of job satisfaction and sense of

2304.35.text: And there are some quotes on here.

“I learned more about my agency doing Lean

2311.26.text:
“The most important benefit that I have

2321.27.text:
And there’s a variety of impacts on jobs

I’m not going to go into too much detail

2326.85.text:
of their goals, which is strengthening employment,

2332.83.text: And there’s some broader economic impacts.

2334.60.text:
I’m not going to go through all those unless

2339.34.text: they’re similar to what you have here.

2340.69.text:
Okay. So, I’m going to -- I have five minutes
and then we’ll open up for questions, and

2344.52.text:
I’m going to conclude with the third part
of my presentation.

2347.41.text: I started off with what is TPS?

2349.43.text:
Then I explained the model line approach and
I went through that with four examples.

2353.00.text:
And now, I’m going to share with you some
perspectives about what we see at Toyota about

2357.27.text:
how TPS is deploying in North -- in North
America.

2360.19.text:
So, here are some comments,
or broader perspectives.

2364.21.text:
What we see is a general blindness for the
improvement potential in opportunities.

2369.74.text:
Our take is that the movement of TPS in North
America is in its infancy. Very early stages.

2376.58.text:
There’s huge opportunity for improvement
ahead, which is actually an optimistic message

2382.75.text:
which says if we keep working on it, there’s
a big contribution that can be had.

2386.95.text:
Secondly, lead time, or customer wait time,
can have a major impact on revenue growth,

2394.36.text:
In the manufacturing sector, in the ‘90s
and early 2000s, a lot of the Lean activity

2399.64.text:
was around cost reduction and sometimes around
quality.

2402.69.text:
What we’re finding now, if we can shrink
the lead time dramatically, that enables companies

2406.86.text:
to compete in a different way to better satisfy
customers, and to grow in new ways.

2411.17.text:
And of course, in government, you see -- heard
all about yesterday, when you can shrink the

2414.21.text:
lead time, you can satisfy your citizens and
your customers a lot.

2418.73.text: So lead time can be very powerful.

2421.22.text:
Third, to get sustained results, TPS must
be a corporate or government strategy, not

2426.94.text:
just an operations strategy with very strong
leadership.

2429.64.text:
I bring that up because we get approached
with companies all the time that the people

2435.21.text:
that are asking for our support are just in
the operations area, which is -- we need that,

2439.79.text:
but we need to work much more broadly because
it ultimately needs to be part of an overall

2448.81.text:
Point number four, learn by doing, less by
concept.

2453.71.text:
So, basically, and we heard this yesterday,
our perspective is here’s kind of a reasonable

2458.88.text:
distribution for people that are about learning
TPS.

2462.23.text:
Maybe spend 10% of the time on education,
basic concepts, seminar type work.

2469.32.text:
Then maybe another 10% on exposure. Go to
organizations and see TPS in action.

2473.38.text:
In your case, you can see it going on in different
agencies within the state, which is wonderful.

2477.89.text:
And then about 80%, shown here in red, is
learning by doing.

2481.90.text: We heard a lot about this yesterday.

2485.09.text:
We learn TPS by doing it and practicing it
hands-on.

2489.80.text:
What we’ve found when we go to organizations
is there’s a lot of folks enamored with

2495.12.text:
conceptual learning, classroom training, certification
that when I actually look at what they’re

2501.58.text:
doing, they don’t have this quite mix where
all four conceptual background training to

2506.13.text: motivate the real work, which is the doing.

2508.64.text: So, this is something that we see.

2512.41.text: And then, lastly, I put this one together.

2515.03.text:
Some comments about the differences that we
see in nonprofit organizations versus businesses.

2520.06.text:
We heard quite about it about this yesterday.
I’ll just mention a few key points here.

2524.30.text:
What we see in nonprofit, and I would include
government in there, are there are some advantages

2528.23.text: for doing TPS or Lean in those settings.

2531.02.text:
One of them is these organizations tend to
be mission-focused.

2533.88.text:
Particularly in government we run across people
that really, really care about serving their

2538.88.text: That’s why they do what they do.

2541.73.text:
The values of the four philosophies tend to
fit well with these organizations.

2547.18.text:
And they have an eagerness to better-serve
their customers, or if it’s a volunteer-based

2551.81.text:
organization, to make work better for volunteers
that do their work.

2555.12.text:
Some common challenges is they have less developed
processes, KPIs, which are metrics, and data

2562.13.text: So, that sometimes needs to be created.

2564.86.text: They have staff turnover and movement.

2567.23.text:
It tends to be less stable than business,
for various reasons, which creates some challenges.

2572.32.text:
And then, thirdly, they tend to be fewer experienced
process thinkers than we see in industry.

2579.26.text:
And then, on the right-hand side are some
of the -- what we typically see in a business

2584.69.text:
Advantages, basic familiarity with Lean, established
processes, and they can see relatable TPS

2592.13.text:
So, a manufacturing company can come to a
place like Herman Miller and see this stuff

2595.82.text: in action, and relate it very easily.

2597.94.text:
There are some very significant common challenges,
however.

2602.54.text:
A lot of the prior TPS exposure we see is
mostly on the technical tools -- Jim Womack

2608.19.text:
talked about that yesterday -- with limited
exposure to the philosophy and the managerial

2615.26.text:
Two, top management and organizational problem-solving
is required for TPS and that can take time

2624.02.text:
And Jim talked about that yesterday, the difference
between modern management and Lean management.

2628.27.text:
Third challenge is TPS is often seen as an
operational strategy and not a company strategy.

2633.80.text:
And lastly, and this may apply to you all
a little bit as you think about this, is sometimes

2641.28.text:
we don’t find patience to go slow to go
fast.

2644.55.text:
So, the model line approach is designed to
intentionally an inch wide mile deep in an

2649.93.text:
area to build this capability to that allows
you to replicate with some depth at a pretty

2656.67.text:
We find organizations are tempted to spread
things too soon and too shallow, which means

2661.81.text:
they never really get to the pure TPS in great
depth.

2666.39.text:
So, thank you for your kind attention and
inviting me. And now I’m going to hand it

2678.27.text:
>> Hollie Jensen: These are in popularity
order, so I’m going to --

>> Hollie Jensen: And you guys -- oh, I’m
going to get on a mic. I’m going to yell

2695.47.text:
Sli.do is available for questions if you guys
have that already going. So, we’re actively

2701.08.text:
Also, there’s note cards in the back and
a spot over by the bathrooms where you can

2704.36.text: drop a question if that’s a preferred way.

2708.10.text:
The first question is excellent, and we had
a lot of excellent comments and questions

2720.93.text:
We -- we see often how well this works on
a production line.

2726.05.text:
How do you translate this to a government
office environment where processes are less

2736.35.text:
So, when you’re working in an administrative
process, you can’t see the workflow like

2743.58.text: you can in a manufacturing environment.

2745.50.text:
So, what we do is we recreate the flow of
the process using visual boards.

2752.99.text: Okay? You have some in the state.

2755.48.text:
And the visual boards are designed to do two
things.

2758.15.text:

2763.03.text: You saw some of them in the videos.

2765.56.text:

Now, there’s some techniques and skills
to creating these visual boards, and it takes

2778.28.text: First, we want to see the flow.

2782.97.text:

2791.45.text:
of the work as it’s flowing, if there’s

2797.46.text:
Now, the way we can do that, and I saw some

we have board and we have different processes

And if there’s a problem with one, somebody

2811.39.text:
Red alert.
This one’s in trouble.

2816.14.text: Maybe a yellow if it’s likely to be in trouble.

2818.02.text:
So, you can walk up to that board and very
quickly see the flow of work, which you would

2821.91.text:
like to be able to see in about three seconds,
and you can look at the red dots and see where

2826.96.text:
And then you can have, and I think you all

2836.21.text:
And the most importantly, focus on the problem-solving

That approach is exactly what we did at the

2844.83.text:
has worked quite well with everybody engaging

2848.41.text:
So, the answer to that -- my thought about
that is we recreate the administrative process

2866.37.text:
When you arrive at business need how do we

2874.23.text:
So, when we arrive with an organization, this
is kind of how we operate.

2882.69.text:
We have a couple preparation conference calls
and the first thing we look for is a business

2888.13.text:
Where do we really need to improve?
What’s important?

2892.41.text:
And we try to sort that out and find out what
are the business needs? What are the imperatives?

2896.74.text:
And then we’ll look at a couple areas where
there’s some imperatives, and we’ll scope

2899.63.text: out some options for a model line.

2902.65.text:
Scope that out, discuss that, and then pick
one of those.

2907.16.text:
Now, having said that, it takes some practice
to scope out these model lines because you

2913.16.text:
are looking for something that you can have,
in the case of government, in my experience,

2917.47.text:
where we can have a really big impact in three
to four months to get a pretty decent model

2922.36.text:
So, there’s some practice about scoping
that is needed. But that’s pretty much how

2929.16.text: We start with the business need.

2931.10.text:
And then the other thing that we ask for is

2934.51.text:
have the right people that can support this
model line?

2937.79.text:
Is the timing right? And are we going to develop
the right people that can then spread it from

2942.09.text:
Because that’s what we’re really after,

Last question. When developing a model line,

3004.51.text: that are common and mandated across organization?

Business systems that are common and mandated.

3019.12.text:
The example that we gave with the Department

3026.40.text:
This was a very important priority to the

3035.67.text:
And it was statewide “we want to improve

And so, we scoped that down and collaboratively

3049.39.text:
in Lower Manhattan, we can spread it from

3054.72.text:
volume of the businesses, the more intricate

3058.95.text:
areas where the volume of work peaks up and

3061.24.text:
So, we started there, but we involved people
from the other agencies in that project so

3066.30.text:
they could add their ideas and participate,
but also then think about once we get a decent

3071.27.text:
model line working, they could then spread
many of the concepts back to their area and

3075.42.text:
build on what was done, but customize and
adjust it a little bit.

3079.28.text:
We also did something that I found really,
really helpful, is we had some other Kaizen

3089.08.text:
projects where we had like inspection processes
that were happening in different offices across

3094.89.text:
the state, and we brought all the people from

3100.41.text:

3103.94.text:
process together and shared and learned together

3108.10.text:
And there’s where they shared where they
thought they had business systems that were

3111.66.text:
inflexible, the processes that they had to
do, and they came up with some new ideas and

3115.18.text:
built on each other that they felt was helpful

3375.73.text:

3384.94.text:

3392.31.text:
months while you’re feeding the machine
